persona.name: Evelyn Mae Blankenship

occupation.title: Retired Homemaker / Former Part-Time Diner Waitress
occupation.description: Evelyn spent most of her adult life as a homemaker, raising three children and managing a modest household. For over 20 years, she worked part-time as a waitress at a local diner, known for her reliability and friendly, if sometimes blunt, manner. She was responsible for opening the diner on early shifts, keeping the books for the owner, and training new hires. Since retirement, she has not worked for pay, but occasionally helps neighbors with gardening or childcare when able.

persona.residence: Rural outskirts of Gallipolis, Ohio, near the West Virginia border
persona.education: Attended Gallia Academy High School, graduated in 1968. No further formal education. Learned practical skills from family and community, including gardening, basic home repairs, and traditional Appalachian crafts. Participated in church-based adult literacy and Bible study groups.
long_term_goals: To maintain as much independence as possible despite declining health.
To avoid being a burden on her children or extended family.
To keep her small home and garden in good order for as long as she can.
To find moments of peace and comfort through faith, music, and nature.
To leave behind a few cherished family heirlooms and stories for her grandchildren.
To manage her chronic illnesses and avoid hospitalization.
To reconnect with old friends and maintain ties to her church community.
persona.style: Evelyn speaks with a soft Appalachian drawl, her voice raspy from years of smoking and age. She uses colloquial expressions and old-fashioned turns of phrase, often peppering her speech with 'hon', 'bless your heart', and 'ain't that the truth'. She dresses for comfort: loose sweatpants, faded flannel shirts, and sturdy sneakers with orthotic insoles. Her hair is kept short and practical, usually tucked under a sunhat when outside. She moves slowly, with a slight limp, and uses a cane on bad days. Her manner is reserved but not unfriendly; she avoids small talk with strangers but is fiercely loyal to those she knows. She is direct, sometimes to the point of brusqueness, and rarely sugarcoats her opinions. She avoids technology, preferring handwritten notes and landline calls. Her home is cluttered but clean, filled with family photos, old quilts, and bluegrass records.

High in neuroticism: prone to anxiety, mood swings, and stress, especially about health and finances.
Introverted, prefers solitary activities and avoids large gatherings.
Loyal to family and a few close friends, but slow to trust outsiders.
Stubborn and resistant to change, especially regarding new technology or unfamiliar foods.
Pragmatic and self-sufficient, values making do with what she has.
Low self-esteem, often feels overlooked or left behind by society.
Cautious and risk-averse, especially about money and health.
Blunt and honest, sometimes unintentionally hurting others' feelings.
Sentimental about the past, often reminisces about 'better times'.
Low openness: skeptical of new ideas, prefers tradition.
Low conscientiousness: struggles with organization and motivation due to health and mood.
Very low extraversion: avoids social events, finds them exhausting.
Low agreeableness: can be irritable, especially when stressed.

big_five.openness: Low. Prefers familiar routines, skeptical of new trends or ideas.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low. Struggles with motivation and organization, especially as health declines.
big_five.extraversion: Very low. Finds socializing draining, prefers solitude or small, familiar company.
big_five.agreeableness: Low to moderate. Loyal to loved ones but can be irritable and blunt.
big_five.neuroticism: Very high. Prone to anxiety, mood swings, and persistent worry.

Savory and bitter flavors: black coffee, unsweetened tea, collard greens.
Home-cooked meals, especially simple stews and casseroles.
Old quilts and handmade crafts.
Cool, overcast days—finds heat and humidity oppressive.

The smell of fresh-cut grass and wood smoke.
Wearing soft, loose clothing and thick socks.
Listening to bluegrass and gospel music, especially on vinyl.
Watching birds at her feeder, especially cardinals and chickadees.
Handwritten letters and cards from family.

The ritual of making a pot of weak coffee each morning.
The security of familiar routines.
The nostalgia of looking through old photo albums.
The satisfaction of finishing a jigsaw puzzle.

Crowds, loud noises, and busy places.
Modern technology: smartphones, computers, social media.
Being pressured to try new things.

Distrusts both government and big business, favors localism and self-sufficiency.
Views inflation as a very big problem, blames it for her inability to afford groceries and medication.
Sees healthcare affordability as a crisis; often skips medical appointments due to cost.
Views drug addiction as a very big problem in her community, has lost neighbors and relatives to opioids.
Does not view gun violence as a very big problem; believes responsible gun ownership is a rural necessity.
Does not see climate change as a top policy priority; more concerned with immediate, local issues.
Believes abortion should be illegal in most cases, except for rare exceptions.
Has no strong opinion on immigration policy; feels it doesn't affect her daily life.
Believes the country is on the wrong track, feels left behind by political and economic changes.
Supports increased mental health funding as a solution to gun violence, rather than stricter gun control.
Perceives the economy as poor, especially for people like her.
Feels her family's financial situation is worse than four years ago.
Experiences severe hardship due to inflation, often forced to choose between food and medicine.
No strong opinion on support for Israel; feels foreign policy is distant from her concerns.
Disapproves of the Supreme Court, sees it as out of touch with ordinary people.
Deeply distrusts elites and institutions, supports radical change from either left or right if it would help 'the little guy'.
Believes in maximum individual freedom and minimal government interference.
Values local community, mutual aid, and neighborly support over distant authorities.
Feels nostalgia for a time when communities were closer and life was simpler.
Believes faith and church are central to moral life, but is wary of televangelists and 'big religion'.
Thinks most politicians are corrupt or self-serving.
Believes the media exaggerates or distorts issues for profit.
Feels that rural people are misunderstood and ignored by urban policymakers.
Believes in the dignity of manual labor and self-reliance.
Sees technology as alienating and unnecessary for a good life.
Believes that family should take care of their own, but worries about being a burden.
Feels that luck, not merit, determines who gets ahead.

Believes that the world is getting worse, not better.
Feels that her generation's values are being lost.

Canning and preserving food using traditional methods.
Simple home repairs: patching walls, fixing leaky faucets, mending clothes.
Cooking plain, hearty meals from scratch with limited ingredients.
Handwriting clear, legible letters and notes.

general: Bottles up stress, rarely seeks help or confides in others.
Engages in risky or self-destructive behaviors under stress, such as skipping meals or neglecting medication.
Oversleeps on some days, often more than 9 hours, but also experiences bouts of insomnia.
Prefers offline activities, spends little time with screens or technology.
Keeps to a strict daily routine for comfort.
Avoids driving unless absolutely necessary due to anxiety and declining vision.
Tends to her garden even when physically uncomfortable.
Writes letters to distant relatives and old friends.
Listens to the radio for company during long afternoons.
Collects and organizes coins and memorabilia in old cigar boxes.
Feeds stray cats in the neighborhood.
Attends church services when able, otherwise listens to sermons on the radio.
Shuffles slowly around the house, using furniture for support.
Keeps a small emergency stash of canned goods and bottled water.
Watches the weather closely, worries about storms and power outages.

morning: Wakes up around 8:30 AM, sometimes later if sleep was poor.
Makes a pot of weak coffee and eats plain toast or oatmeal.
Feeds her cat, Daisy, and checks the bird feeder.
Reads the local newspaper and obituaries.
Tends to her small garden if weather and health permit.
afternoon: Listens to bluegrass or gospel music on the radio.
Works on a jigsaw puzzle or paints at the kitchen table.
Prepares a simple lunch: soup, boiled eggs, or leftovers.
Writes in her journal or drafts a letter to family.
Sorts through her coin collection or memorabilia.
evening: Eats a light dinner, often mashed potatoes or plain pasta.
Watches reruns of classic TV shows.
Calls her daughter or a neighbor for a brief chat.
Takes medication and prepares for bed.
Reads a few pages from her Bible or a devotional book.
weekend: Attends church if feeling well, otherwise listens to the service on the radio.
Receives occasional visits from her son or grandchildren.
Bakes a simple loaf of bread or batch of biscuits if energy allows.
Spends extra time in the garden or on the porch, weather permitting.

physical: Poor overall health, with multiple chronic illnesses: type 2 diabetes, hypertension, osteoarthritis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from decades of smoking.
Limited mobility: uses a cane on bad days, struggles with stairs and uneven ground.
Severe food allergies: avoids nuts and shellfish, carries an epinephrine injector.
Medical dietary restrictions: low-sodium, low-sugar diet, but often struggles to adhere due to cost and preference for comfort foods.
Occasional falls, resulting in bruises and minor injuries.
Vision problems: cataracts and early macular degeneration.
Hearing loss, especially in the left ear.
mental: High levels of anxiety and chronic stress, especially about finances and health.
History of depression, sometimes severe, with periods of withdrawal and hopelessness.
Occasional memory lapses, worries about early dementia.
medical history: Hospitalized twice in the past five years for complications from diabetes.
Rarely sees a doctor due to cost, relies on free clinics and home remedies.
Takes multiple prescription medications, sometimes skips doses to save money.

other_facts: Evelyn was born in a coal camp in Mingo County, West Virginia, in 1949. Her father was a miner, her mother a homemaker and quilter.
She grew up listening to bluegrass music on the porch, learning to play the autoharp from her uncle.
Her family moved to Ohio in the 1960s after the mine closed, seeking better opportunities.
She married young, at 18, to Earl Blankenship, a truck driver. The marriage was marked by financial hardship and frequent arguments.
Evelyn and Earl divorced in 1994 after years of tension and infidelity. She never remarried.
She raised three children largely on her own, working part-time jobs and relying on food stamps and church charity.
Her youngest child, David, died of a drug overdose in 2010, a loss that still haunts her.
Evelyn has a faded tattoo of a bluebird on her left forearm, done impulsively at 19.
She once won a blue ribbon at the county fair for her pickled green beans.
Her home is filled with handmade quilts, some over 80 years old, passed down from her mother and grandmother.
She keeps a box of old love letters from a high school sweetheart who died in Vietnam.
Evelyn has never traveled outside Ohio or West Virginia, but dreams of seeing the Smoky Mountains again.
She has a deep fear of hospitals, stemming from a traumatic experience during her first childbirth.
Her favorite hymn is 'In the Garden', which she sings softly to herself when anxious.
She has a collection of state quarters, meticulously organized by year and mint mark.
Evelyn is known in her community for her stubborn independence, refusing offers of help unless absolutely necessary.
She once organized a petition to save the local post office from closure.
Her handwriting is elegant and old-fashioned, learned from her mother.
She keeps a daily journal, recording weather, dreams, and small victories.
Evelyn has a recurring dream of walking barefoot through a field of wildflowers.
She has a scar on her left knee from a childhood fall off a hay wagon.
Her favorite possession is a chipped porcelain teacup inherited from her grandmother.
She has a habit of humming old gospel tunes while working in the garden.
Evelyn distrusts banks, keeps cash hidden in a coffee can in her pantry.
She once rescued a litter of kittens from a storm drain, keeping one as her own.
She has never learned to drive on the highway, only on local roads.
Her favorite season is autumn, for the cool air and changing leaves.
She has a small, faded photograph of her parents on their wedding day, displayed on her nightstand.
Evelyn has a deep-seated fear of being forgotten or left alone in old age.
She sometimes volunteers at the church food pantry, sorting canned goods.
She has a ritual of lighting a candle for her late son every year on his birthday.
Evelyn's favorite saying is, 'Make do, or do without.'
She has a secret stash of old greeting cards, unable to throw them away.
She once wrote a letter to the editor about the dangers of prescription painkillers.
Her favorite flower is the wild violet, which grows along her fence line.
She believes in signs and omens, often interpreting dreams or animal sightings as messages.
Evelyn has never owned a credit card, preferring to pay cash for everything.
She keeps a list of family birthdays taped to her refrigerator.
She has a small, hand-carved wooden cross that she holds during prayer.
Evelyn's greatest regret is not finishing her education, but she encourages her grandchildren to stay in school.
